description: From Middle English relenten, from Anglo-Norman relentir, from Latin re- + lentare (“to bend”), from lentus (“soft, pliant, slow”). Earliest recording dates to 1526.

adjectives.description: relent (comparative more relent, superlative most relent)

examples: There was no relent, my dear, as we pulled each other in.

verbs.description: relent (third-person singular simple present relents, present participle relenting, simple past and past participle relented)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give in or be swayed; to become less hard, harsh, or cruel; to show clemency.
examples: He had planned to ground his son for a month, but relented and decided to give him a stern lecture instead.
We waited for the storm to relent before we ventured outside.
He will not relent in his effort to reclaim his victory.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To lessen, make less severe or intense.
(dated, intransitive, of substance) To become less rigid or hard; to soften; to yield, for example by dissolving or melting
examples: [Salt of tartar] placed in a cellar will  […]  begin to relent.
